title: Neighborhood Assemblies Rise
outcome: Neighborhood assemblies rapidly take over civic functions, establishing local, public voting sessions in place of BCI-based services. The official Council is sidelined as citizens organize mutual aid, bypassing malfunctioning central systems. Directorate attempts to disrupt assemblies are publicly exposed, driving a shift in loyalty toward local leaders. Tensions remain as assemblies face resource challenges and accusations of exclusion, but a sense of agency and solidarity grows.

events.description: Informal assemblies begin meeting in city halls and community centers, organizing public voting to resolve service issues, supplanting BCI-based decisions.
Directorate loyalists attempt to undermine assemblies with rigged records and disruptions; incidents are caught on citizen livestreams, leading to mass outrage and Directorate retreats.
Mutual aid networks flourish. Local leaders coordinate food, transit, and welfare support. Council official channels become inactive, losing authority.
Resource shortfalls and accusations of favoritism strain some assemblies, but they negotiate publicly and open records, restoring trust and building stronger coalitions.
